Article.ArticleTitle: Acute effects of air pollutants on spontaneous pregnancy loss: a case-crossover study.

AbstractText: To investigate the relationship between acute exposure to air pollutants and spontaneous pregnancy loss.
An academic emergency department in the Wasatch Front area of Utah.
A total of 1,398 women who experienced spontaneous pregnancy loss events.

We found that a 10-ppb increase in 7-day average levels of nitrogen dioxide was associated with a 16% increase in the odds of spontaneous pregnancy loss (odds ratio [OR] = 1.16; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.01-1.33; P=.04). A 10-μg/m<sup>3</sup> increase in 3-day and 7-day averages of fine particulate matter were associated with increased risk of spontaneous pregnancy loss, but the associations did not reach statistical significance (OR<sub>3-day average</sub> = 1.09; 95% CI 0.99-1.20; P=.05) (OR<sub>7-day average</sub> = 1.11; 95% CI 0.99-1.24; P=.06). We found no evidence of increased risk for any other metrics of nitrogen dioxide or fine particulate matter or any metric for ozone.
We found that short-term exposure to elevated levels of air pollutants was associated with higher risk for spontaneous pregnancy loss.
